summary.p: The manuscript contains the Ciṟuppapāyiram, Potuppāyiram and Eḻuttatikāram of the Naṉṉūl with the commentary by Caṅkaranamaccivāyar, styled Naṉṉūluraipāṭam Caṅkaranamacivāyam in the margin titles and published under the title Viruttiyurai as edited by Āṟumukanāvalaravar, 1860.

msItem.title: Naṉṉūl Eḻuttatikāram with the commentary of Caṅkaranamaccivāyar (Viruttiyurai)
msItem.author: Pavaṇanti, Caṅkaranamaccivāyar

extent.measure: There are two unnumbered leaves at the beginning and one blank numbered leaf at the end.

supportDesc.foliation: 2 initial leaves are unnumbered thereafter all leaves are numbered on the recto, middle left margin in Tamil numerals ending with 166. Arabic numerals are written below the Tamil numerals on all but the last leaf.
supportDesc.condition: The leaves are in impeccable condition.

layoutDesc.layout: Scriptio continua throughout with section titles in the margin as well as the initial syllables of verses/cūttirams. On the second unnumbered leaf four verses are written in three columns divided by the string holes. The cūttirams are numbered in the body of the text at the end of the commentary. An equals sign (=) surrounds the number.

handNote.desc: Fairly regular, neat hand, probably Ducler's scribe.

desc.p:
On the recto of a slip of paper is written in ink the following title in cursive script:
mr Ducler No 30
intitulé Nannoule, ou grammaire, Tamoul
2ème Partie
Solliyal, ou Etymologie, (ouvrage anonyme)
contenant 203 feuilles.
This is incorrect and belongs to the second part of the manuscript containing the second chapter of the Naṉṉūl, the Collatikāram, Indien 180.

Centered on the recto of the first unnumbered leaf is incised and inked the following title in cursive script as is typical of manuscripts in the Ducler collection:
Grammaire Malabare
Orthographie.

On the recto of the second unnumbered leaf the following blessings and title are written in the left margin:

binding.p: Wooden cover boards and string. 170 mm between stringholes.

origin.origDate: The date given in Cabaton's catalog (p. 30) is likely approximate, but as the manuscript belongs to the collection of Ducler, it must have been produced around this time.

provenance.p: One of the manuscripts Ducler had copied while working in Karaikal.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Bibliothèque Nationale in 1833 (Ducler's collection).

encodingDesc.p: Tamil text has been given twice: once in Tamil script approximating as closely as possible the text as it appears in the manuscript. The transliterated text, however, is interpretative in that it follows how the text would be printed in a modern edition with puḷḷis long ē/ō, etc.
